verses.text: In the thirtieth year, in the fourth month, on the fifth day, as I was among the exiles by the Kebar River, the heavens opened, and I saw visions from God.
verses.comment: Ezekiel recounts his first prophetic encounter in exile. The opening of the heavens and visions recall other theophanies (see Gen. 28:12, Jacob's ladder). Note the historical detail and connection to Babylonian exile—a time when God still revealed Himself outside Jerusalem.

verses.text: On the fifth day of the month—it was the fifth year of exile for King Jehoiachin—
verses.comment: Provides a precise historical setting rooted in the Babylonian exile. This grounding in history gives credibility and context to the prophetic message.

verses.text: The word of the Lord came to Ezekiel the priest, son of Buzi, in the land of the Chaldeans by the Kebar River. The hand of the Lord was upon him there.
verses.comment: Ezekiel's priestly identity is highlighted. The phrase 'hand of the Lord' marks divine empowerment for mission. Even outside the Promised Land, God's word and grace are not limited by geography.

verses.text: I looked, and saw a stormy wind coming from the north—a great cloud with brightness around it and fire flashing forth continually, and in the midst of the fire something like gleaming metal.
verses.comment: God's glory is revealed in dramatic, fearful imagery similar to Sinai (Exod. 19:18). Fire and brightness emphasize God’s transcendence.

verses.text: From the midst of it came four living creatures. Their appearance was like that of a human being,
verses.comment: The four living creatures symbolize angelic representatives of God's power and authority. Compare to the heavenly vision in Revelation 4:6, suggesting continuity in biblical imagery.

verses.text: but each had four faces, and each of them had four wings.
verses.comment: Four faces and four wings highlight their otherworldliness, pointing to the heavenly realm where creation's fullness worships God. The number four may symbolize completeness.

verses.text: Their legs were straight, and the soles of their feet were like the sole of a calf’s foot. They sparkled like polished bronze.
verses.comment: Details reinforce their purity and strength, echoing similar descriptions of Christ’s glorified appearance in Revelation 1:15. Their shimmering, metallic appearance hints at holiness.

verses.text: Under their wings on all four sides were human hands. Each creature had faces and wings as follows:
verses.comment: Human hands suggest intelligence and purposeful action—God’s messengers actively serve His will.

verses.text: Their wings touched one another. Each did not turn as they moved; each went straight forward.
verses.comment: The creatures’ unwavering direction shows perfect obedience and unity in carrying God’s commands.

verses.text: Their faces were like this: each had a human face in front; the face of a lion on the right; the face of an ox on the left; and the face of an eagle at the back.
verses.comment: Traditionally, these faces have been understood to symbolize aspects of creation or messianic qualities: humanity (wisdom), lion (kingship), ox (servanthood), eagle (divinity and transcendence). See the typology echoed in Revelation 4:7 and in later Christian iconography.

verses.text: Such were their faces. Their wings were spread upward; two wings of each touched another, and two covered their bodies.
verses.comment: The gesture recalls seraphim in Isaiah 6:2—covering themselves in reverence before God’s glory.

verses.text: Each went straight forward wherever the spirit wanted to go; they did not turn when they moved.
verses.comment: The spirit guides their movement—emphasizing God’s sovereign initiative. Compare with John 3:8 on the Spirit’s mysterious, sovereign activity.

verses.text: In the midst of the living creatures appeared something like burning coals of fire, like torches moving to and fro among them. The fire was bright, and lightning flashed from it.
verses.comment: Fire and lightning point to God’s active, purifying presence. Compare to Exodus 13:21, God leading by pillar of fire.

verses.text: And the living creatures moved back and forth as quickly as lightning.
verses.comment: Their swift movement shows energy and readiness to serve, echoing Psalm 104:4—God’s angels as 'winds, ministers of flaming fire.'

verses.text: As I looked at the living creatures, I saw a wheel on the ground beside each one.
verses.comment: God’s throne chariot is depicted—wheels signal movement and omnipresence. Compare Ezekiel 10 for repeated imagery.

verses.text: The appearance of the wheels and their workings looked like sparkling beryl. All four had the same likeness, and their form was like that of a wheel within a wheel.
verses.comment: Beryl is a precious stone symbolizing radiance. 'Wheel within a wheel' suggests multidimensional movement, underlining that God's glory cannot be confined to human limitations.

verses.text: When they moved, they went in any of their four directions without turning as they went.
verses.comment: Perfect mobility, unrestricted, symbolizing God’s ability to be present everywhere and act freely in creation.

verses.text: Their rims were tall and awe-inspiring, and their rims were full of eyes all around the four of them.
verses.comment: Eyes symbolize knowledge, awareness, and vigilance. Nothing escapes the gaze of the divine presence.

verses.text: When the living creatures moved, the wheels moved alongside them; and when the creatures rose from the earth, the wheels rose,
verses.comment: The inseparable movement reflects close cooperation between God's messengers and the instrument of His glory. Spiritual and physical realms unite in God's action.

verses.text: Wherever the spirit wanted to go, the creatures went, and the wheels rose along with them, for the spirit of the living creatures was in the wheels.
verses.comment: God’s Spirit drives all action, visible even in the vision’s machinery. This harmony foreshadows themes of guidance and sanctification by the Spirit, later prominent in the New Testament.

verses.text: When the creatures moved, the wheels moved; when they stood still, the wheels stood still. When the creatures rose from the earth, the wheels rose with them, for the spirit of the living creatures was in the wheels.
verses.comment: Repetition stresses the union between spiritual beings and the mechanisms of divine presence.

verses.text: Over the heads of the living creatures was something like an expanse, shining like crystal, stretched out above their heads.
verses.comment: The expanse or firmament mirrors creation’s order and separation; it also suggests heaven’s glory and the transcendent throne (cf. Rev. 4:6, ‘sea of glass’).

verses.text: Under the expanse, their wings were stretched out toward one another. Each had two wings covering their bodies.
verses.comment: The creatures show reverence with covered bodies, pointing to the need for humility before God’s glory.

verses.text: When they moved, I heard the sound of their wings like the roar of mighty waters, like the voice of the Almighty, like the noise of an army. When they stopped, they lowered their wings.
verses.comment: God’s presence is overwhelming—compare the sound to God’s ‘voice’ in Ps. 29:3 and Christ’s voice in Rev. 1:15. Awe and reverence frame the vision.

verses.text: A voice came from above the expanse over their heads; whenever they stood still, they lowered their wings.
verses.comment: Divine speech from above recalls the creative word in Genesis 1:3—here, reinforcing that God communicates from the highest heaven.

verses.text: Above the expanse over their heads was something like a throne, appearing like sapphire stone, and seated above the likeness of the throne was a figure with a human appearance.
verses.comment: A throne signals kingship; the figure 'like a human' foreshadows the incarnational themes fulfilled in the New Testament. Compare Rev. 4:2 and typologically see divine condescension to be present with humanity.

verses.text: From the waist up, it looked like gleaming metal, with fire all around. From the waist down, I saw what looked like fire, with radiance all around.
verses.comment: This fiery, radiant figure evokes divine majesty and holiness, resonating with other appearances of God or Christ (Ezek. 8:2; Rev. 1:15).

verses.text: Like the appearance of the bow in the cloud on a rainy day, so was the radiance surrounding Him. This was the appearance of the likeness of the glory of the Lord. When I saw it, I fell face down, and I heard the voice of one speaking.
verses.comment: The rainbow recalls God’s covenant with Noah (Gen. 9:13)—symbolizing hope, mercy, and faithfulness. Falling face down is a standard biblical reaction to divine glory (see Rev. 1:17); tradition sees this as the necessary posture of worship before God, suggesting the deep reverence and sacramental awe expected of believers in God’s presence.
